title: 107_s1541
content: The title of the act is the "Temporary Emergency Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001". It also includes provisions regarding Federal-State agreements. Any State may enter into an agreement with the Secretary of Labor to provide temporary emergency unemployment compensation to individuals who have exhausted all rights to regular compensation under State law. The agreement can be terminated with a 30-day notice. For temporary emergency unemployment compensation, individuals must have exhausted all regular compensation rights under State law, have no rights to compensation from any other source, and not be receiving compensation from Canada's unemployment law for that week. Exhaustion of Benefits occurs when an individual has received all available regular compensation under State law or when their rights to compensation have expired due to the end of the benefit year. Exhaustion of Benefits happens when an individual has received all available regular compensation under State law or when their rights to compensation have expired due to the end of the benefit year. The amount of temporary emergency unemployment compensation payable to an individual for a week of total unemployment is equal to the regular compensation they would receive under the State law for a week of total unemployment. The terms and conditions of the State law apply to claims for temporary emergency unemployment compensation, with the maximum amount payable to any individual determined by their regular compensation for a week of total unemployment. The Governor of a State can elect to trigger off an extended compensation period to provide temporary emergency unemployment compensation to individuals who have exhausted their regular compensation rights under State law. The maximum amount payable to any individual is determined by their regular compensation for a week of total unemployment. SEC. 3. TEMPORARY EMERGENCY UNEMPLOYMENT COMPENSATION ACCOUNT. The State will establish temporary emergency unemployment compensation accounts for eligible individuals, with the amount in the account being 13 times the individual's average weekly benefit amount for the benefit year. The amount may be reduced for extended benefits. The State establishes temporary emergency unemployment compensation accounts for eligible individuals, with the amount in the account being 13 times the individual's average weekly benefit amount for the benefit year. The amount may be reduced for extended benefits received under the Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970. The regular compensation amount payable to an individual for total unemployment is determined under the State law, including dependents' allowances. SEC. 4. PAYMENTS TO STATES WITH AGREEMENTS FOR TEMPORARY EMERGENCY UNEMPLOYMENT COMPENSATION. Payments to states with agreements for temporary emergency unemployment compensation shall be equal to 100 percent of the compensation paid to individuals under the agreement. No payment shall be made if the state is entitled to reimbursement under any other federal law. A State with an agreement for temporary emergency unemployment compensation will not receive reimbursement under chapter 85 of title 5, United States Code if reimbursement is already received under this title. Payments to states will be determined by the Secretary in advance or as reimbursement based on estimated entitlements for each month. The Secretary will adjust the payments to states based on actual entitlements for each month, accounting for any overpayments or underpayments from previous months. The estimation method will be agreed upon by the Secretary and the State agency. SEC. 5. FINANCING PROVISIONS. Funds in the extended unemployment compensation account shall be used for payments to States with agreements under this title. The Secretary certifies sums payable to each State for payment by the Secretary of the Treasury. Prior to audit or settlement by the General Accounting Office, payments are made to the State from the extended unemployment compensation account to the State's account in the Unemployment Trust Fund. Funds are appropriated without fiscal year limitation to assist States in meeting the costs of administration of agreements under this title. Appropriations for certain payments are authorized from the general fund of the Treasury. Authorization of appropriations from the general fund of the Treasury, without fiscal year limitation, to the extended unemployment compensation account of the Unemployment Trust Fund for payments under chapter 85 of title 5, United States Code, and compensation based on services under section 3309(a)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amounts appropriated under section 3309(a)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 do not need to be repaid. SEC. 6. FRAUD AND OVERPAYMENTS. If an individual knowingly makes a false statement or fails to disclose a material fact to receive unauthorized temporary emergency unemployment compensation, they will be ineligible for further benefits according to state laws on fraud in unemployment claims. In cases of fraudulent claims for emergency unemployment compensation, individuals must repay the amounts received and may face prosecution under federal law. Repayment may be waived by the State agency under certain circumstances. The State agency may waive repayment of emergency unemployment compensation if it was without fault on the individual's part and repayment would be against equity. The agency can recover the amount by deducting from future unemployment compensation. Repayment can be recovered by deducting from future unemployment compensation, with a limit of 3 years after the overpayment. Repayment can be recovered by deducting from future unemployment compensation, with a limit of 3 years after the overpayment. The temporary emergency unemployment compensation to which they were not entitled may have deductions up to 50 percent of the weekly benefit amount. Repayment and deductions are only made after a fair hearing and final determination. Any determination by a State agency under this section is subject to review in the same manner and to the same extent. Any determination by a State agency under this section shall be subject to review in the same manner and to the same extent as determinations under the State unemployment compensation law. SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. This title defines key terms such as compensation, benefit year, and week according to the Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970. SEC. 8. APPLICABILITY. SEC. 8. APPLICABILITY. An agreement under this Act applies to unemployment weeks starting after the agreement and ending within 18 months of the Act's enactment. SEC. 9. TEMPORARY REDUCTION IN INTEREST RATE FOR STATE UNEMPLOYMENT FUND ADVANCES. SEC. 9. TEMPORARY REDUCTION IN INTEREST RATE APPLICABLE TO STATE UNEMPLOYMENT FUND ADVANCES: The interest rate paid by a State on advances under the Social Security Act will be reduced from 10 percent to 5 percent for 18 months after the enactment of this Act.
